unit: Unit 8 | Inference for Categorical Data: Chi-Square
title: Termites | 2 of 2
question_text: Termites are starting to become a big problem in a large city. Two different chemicals, chemicals A and B, are typically used to exterminate termites. Forty homes are treated with chemical A, and another forty are treated with chemical B. Forty homes are treated with a mixture of chemicals A and B, and another forty homes are treated with nothing (as a control group). Six months after the chemicals were used, the homes were examined to determine if all the termites were exterminated. This information is represented in the table below: Termites Exterminated Termites NOT Exterminated Chemical A 28 12 Chemical B 27 13 Both Chemicals A and B 28 12 Neither Chemical  (control) 7 33 Assume the homes were randomly selected and that each had a similar termite condition. Suppose a chi-squared test shows strong evidence each treatment is not equally effective. How might these results be misleading?

choices.text: Conditions for chi-squared procedures were not met.
All chemical treatments were about equally effective.
The control group did just as well as every other treatment.
A chi-squared test would not be the appropriate inferential procedure in this situation.
